Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the development of analogical processing in infants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning by analogy is a powerful and efficient method for acquiring new information. The goal of this research program is to trace the origins of analogical ability in human infants, using the simplest and most basic relation--that of sameness and difference between two things. The proposed research will identify the scope of infants' ability to detect same-different relations. Certainly infants do not have the same higher-order relational abilities of children and adults. This research will 1) identify the earliest evidence of relational learning processes in the first months of life; 2) trace its developmental trajectory over the first year; and 3) characterize the interplay between language and early relational ability.

The research addresses the key question of when children begin to think abstractly and how this ability can be fostered. Studies of early relational learning processes will provide insight into the conceptual capacities that are critical to higher-order learning in childhood and beyond. Further, the studies of interactions with language may lead to better understanding of the role of cultural and linguistic experience in conceptual development. The patterns revealed by these experiments will give parents and educators the requisite knowledge to support relational learning in STEM disciplines. They may also enable practitioners to identify patterns that deviate from typical development and suggest targeted interventions for children with cognitive or linguistic impairments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Analogical ability is the ability to make relational comparisons between objects, events, or ideas, and to think about relations independently of a particular set of elements. Learning by analogy is a powerful and efficient method for acquiring new information and may be the key difference between human cognitive capacity and that of other apes. Little is known about the origins of human analogical ability, although there has been considerable research on the development of analogical ability from preschool to adulthood. This grant traces the origins of analogical ability in human infants, using the simplest and most basic relation – that of sameness and difference between two things. The research identified the scope of infants’ ability to detect same-different relations. It is clear that infants do not have the same higher-order relational abilities found in children and adults. The grant has provided evidence that there are specific learning conditions that facilitate relational comparison and others that hinder performance.

This grant is first to identify evidence of relational learning processes in 2-month-old infants. In addition, the research reveals the developmental trajectory of relational abilities over the first year. In particular we have new insights about the role of language in learning relations. These findings begin to characterize the interplay between language and early relational ability. The research demonstrated that infants can think abstractly as early as 2 months of age and we have new insights about how this ability can be fostered. Our studies of early relational learning processes provide insight into the conceptual capacities that are critical to higher order learning in childhood and beyond. Further, our studies of interactions with language will lead to better understanding of the role of cultural and linguistic experience in conceptual development. These studies also have implications for comparative psychology; our findings lay the groundwork for a more definitive understanding of relational ability across species. The patterns revealed by these experiments give parents and educators the requisite knowledge to support relational learning in STEM disciplines and other arenas. In addition, our findings enable practitioners to better identify patterns that deviate from typical development, and it suggests targeted interventions for children with cognitive or linguistic impairments.
